bestBHT.bht: Luke's Gospel contains reliable accounts drawn from the oral tradition of the apostles, who personally witnessed Jesus' ministry. The word preached, referring to the gospel message, formed the basis of these narratives. Luke's focus is on the commencement of Jesus' public ministry, highlighting the credibility of the previous stories. It is worth noting that Luke did not have access to the Gospel of Matthew and did not receive his information from the Apostle Paul.

Henry Alford: The Apostles, delivered these matters orally to the Churches in their teaching... Their account of these matters was a tradition, from which the narrations were drawn up.
He cannot therefore have seen (or, having seen, not recognized as such, which is highly improbable) the Gospel of St. Matthew.
of the word—not, ‘the personal word’ (i.e., Christ: so Orig., Athanasius, Cyril, Euthym.) which would be altogether alien from St. Luke’s usage... but, the word, ‘the word preached.'
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: of His public ministry, as is plain from what follows.
Albert Barnes: From the beginning - From the commencement of these things - that is, from the birth of John, or perhaps from the beginning of the ministry of Jesus.
Eye-witnesses - Who had seen those things themselves, and who were therefore proper witnesses.
Ministers of the word - The term 'word' here means the 'gospel.' Luke never uses it, as John does, to denote the second Person of the Trinity.
Marvin Vincent: Even as. Referring to the composition of the narrative. Delivered [παρεδοσαν] . Not necessarily excluding written traditions, but referring mainly to oral tradition."
From the beginning [απ αρχης] . The official beginning, the commencement of Jesus ' ministry.
Eye witnesses and ministers. Personal knowledge and practical experience were necessary elements of an apostle.
Philip Schaff: The oral instruction of the Apostles is here referred to.
From the beginning, i.e., from the baptism of John.
The word, i.e., the word of the gospel, the preached word.
Archibald T. Robertson: Luke asserts that the previous narratives had their sound basis.
Luke means to say that the handing down [of tradition] was dependable, not mere wives' fables.
Here 'the word' means the gospel message.
John Gill: The twelve apostles, and seventy disciples...handed down to others the accounts of the birth, life, and death of Christ."
They were eyewitnesses of him, of the truth of his incarnation, and of his ministry and miracles."
Luke was not one of the seventy disciples...nor did he take his account from the Apostle Paul.

bhtAttempts.bht: According to the commentaries, the accounts in Luke's Gospel were derived from the oral tradition passed down by the apostles, who personally witnessed Jesus and his ministry. Luke emphasizes that the word preached was dependable and not mere wives' fables. He begins his narrative from the commencement of Jesus' public ministry, affirming the sound basis of the previous narratives. The term 'word' here refers to the gospel message. It is important to note that Luke did not see or recognize the Gospel of Matthew, and he did not take his account from the Apostle Paul.

Luke's Gospel contains reliable accounts drawn from the oral tradition of the apostles, who personally witnessed Jesus' ministry. The word preached, referring to the gospel message, formed the basis of these narratives. Luke's focus is on the commencement of Jesus' public ministry, highlighting the credibility of the previous stories. It is worth noting that Luke did not have access to the Gospel of Matthew and did not receive his information from the Apostle Paul.

The narratives in Luke's Gospel were based on reliable accounts handed down orally by the apostles themselves, who witnessed the ministry of Jesus. Luke emphasizes the dependability of the preached word, which formed the foundation for these stories. He specifically begins his narrative from the commencement of Jesus' public ministry, affirming the credibility of the preceding accounts. Importantly, Luke did not rely on the Gospel of Matthew or receive his information directly from the Apostle Paul.

Luke's Gospel is built upon the trustworthy accounts passed down orally by the apostles. These narratives were drawn from a tradition that provided a reliable foundation for Luke's composition. The apostles' firsthand knowledge and practical experience ensured the credibility of their testimonies. Luke specifically starts his account from the beginning of Jesus' public ministry, reinforcing the sound basis of the previous narratives. It is worth noting that Luke did not rely on the Gospel of Matthew or receive his information directly from the Apostle Paul.

The narratives in Luke's Gospel are built upon the reliable oral tradition passed down by the apostles, ensuring their credibility. Luke specifically starts his account from the beginning of Jesus' public ministry, emphasizing the sound basis of the preceding stories. The apostles' firsthand knowledge and practical experience were vital elements in their role as eyewitnesses and ministers of the gospel. It is worth noting that Luke did not rely on the Gospel of Matthew or receive his information directly from the Apostle Paul.
